text.5:
This verse warns people who oppose Allah and His Messenger, by choosing laws that apply to themselves other than the laws that Allah and His Messenger have established, and embracing religions other than those He has prescribed. They will be afflicted with torment in the form of humiliation during their life in this world, as has befallen those of the past who denied the Messengers whom Allah sent to them.

This verse is good news and adds to the spirit of the Muslims who are experiencing pressure from those allied in the Battle of the Trench (Ahzab). At that time, the Jews, the polytheists of Mecca, and the hypocrites united and allied themselves against the Muslims, so that their numbers were far greater than the number of Muslims. Because of the high spirit of the Muslims and their belief in Allah's help that would be given to them, they were able to defeat the allied army.

This verse is a warning to leaders that they will be held accountable by Allah in the Hereafter, whether they have implemented Allah's laws in their government. Because Allah has affirmed that the law and religion that humans are allowed to adhere to is only Islam. Apart from that, humans are forbidden to follow and embrace it. Allah says:

"This day I have perfected for you your religion and completed My favor upon you and have approved for you Islam as religion. But whoever is forced by severe hunger with no inclination to sin - then indeed, Allah is Forgiving and Merciful." (Al-Ma'idah/5: 3)

The religion of Islam referred to is the religion preached by the Prophet Muhammad, which he received from Allah.

Meanwhile, regarding matters that have been determined, rulers or people who represent their people are allowed to establish other laws that regulate the lives of their communities, as long as those laws do not conflict with the laws that Allah has established.

It is explained that Allah has revealed His verses to the Prophet Muhammad, which present strong arguments and evidence for the truth of religion and its laws. No one can refute the arguments and evidence, even if they still deny and violate those laws.

From these verses, it can be understood that Allah commands humans, especially intellectuals, to study and discuss Allah's laws, using their reason, thoughts, and experience, even with all the abilities they possess. Then give an accurate and objective assessment.

In verse 4, it was said, "Wa lil-kafirina 'adhabun alim" (and for the disbelievers is a painful punishment), while in this fifth verse it is said, "Wa lil kafirina 'adhabun muhin" (and for the disbelievers is a humiliating punishment). What is meant by the disbelievers in verse 4 are believing people who violate the provisions. They receive a painful punishment as a lesson for them to immediately repent and realize their mistakes. While what is meant by the disbelievers in this fifth verse are those who are truly disbelievers, who do not believe. For them is a torment that causes humiliation during their life in this world, such as the loss of shame in themselves, feeling normal doing forbidden things, feeling normal cheating and committing vile acts. People like that are usually people in power who can do everything they want, but other people no longer have appreciation in the true sense of the word for them. There are many more forms of heavier humiliation that they receive.
text.6: This verse explains the state of those who oppose and violate Allah's law in the afterlife. Allah gathers them all, from the first human being, Adam, until the last moment of human life, on the Day of Judgment. Then, Allah informs them of what they did during their lives in the world. All of it is recorded in their respective books of records; nothing is forgotten, even if they themselves have forgotten it, because nothing escapes Allah's knowledge.
text.7:
This verse explains how vast, deep, and complete Allah's knowledge is concerning the creatures He created, from the smallest to the largest. It is explained that Allah's knowledge encompasses everything in the heavens and the earth, no matter how small and subtle. If there are three people in the heavens and the earth whispering, then Allah is the fourth. If those whispering and holding secret consultations are four people, then Allah is the fifth, and if those whispering and holding secret consultations are five people, then Allah is the sixth. Indeed, no matter how many people whisper and hold secret consultations, and wherever they do it, Allah certainly knows.

The mention of the numbers three, four, and five people in the verse is only to state that usually consultations are carried out by several people such as three, four, five, and so on, and Allah certainly witnesses each consultation. Allah says:

"Do they not know that Allah knows their secrets and their private conversations, and that Allah is the Knower of the unseen?" (at-Taubah/9: 78)

And He says:

"Or do they think that We do not hear their secrets and their private conversations? Yes [We do], and Our messengers [angels] are with them, recording." (az-Zukhruf/43: 80)

At the end of this verse, Allah affirms that the truth about Allah being All-Knowing of everything will only be known by them on the Day of Judgment, namely when their records of deeds are presented, in which are recorded all the actions they have ever done during their life in the world, whether good or bad deeds, not a single one is forgotten to be recorded. At that time, the disbelievers will only regret their actions, but regret in the future is of no use whatsoever.
text.8:
This verse condemns the actions of the Jews who engaged in actions that provoked discord and animosity between themselves and the Muslims, despite a peace agreement having been established between them. The Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him) warned them about their attitude, but they ignored it.

Their whispering conversations actually magnified their sins before Allah. This sin was because they had violated the peace agreement they had made with the Messenger of Allah, that they and the Muslims would maintain tranquility and strive to create a peaceful atmosphere in the city of Medina. They were at fault because they were constantly looking for opportunities to destroy the Muslims and thwart the da'wah of Prophet Muhammad.

When those Jews met or came to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him), they offered greetings, but the content was insulting to the Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him). 'Aisha responded with a harsher reply, because the attitude and actions of the Jews had gone too far, both in terms of politeness in social interaction and in terms of the customs that prevailed at that time.

From the perspective of Islam, the actions of the Jews had truly gone too far, because Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him) was a prophet and messenger of Allah, for whom every Muslim prays for safety and goodness. Allah Almighty says:

Indeed, Allah confers blessing upon the Prophet, and His angels [ask Him to do so]. O you who have believed, ask [ Allah to confer] blessing upon him and ask [ Allah to grant him] peace. (al-Ahzab/33: 56)

From the above verse and the reasons for its revelation, it can be understood that we should be patient with the vile words thrown at us. Do not immediately retaliate as they do, because that is where the difference lies between a Muslim and a disbeliever. By being patient, they will realize and be aware that they have made a mistake.

After the Jews uttered insulting greetings to the Messenger of Allah as mentioned above, they said to each other, "Why doesn't Allah inflict punishment on us as a result of Muhammad's answer? If Muhammad were truly a prophet and messenger sent by Allah, we would have been struck by punishment." Their assumption about Allah, that Allah would immediately punish everyone who disobeyed Him, is a false assumption. It is true that He will punish everyone who disobeys Him, but when that punishment will come is His affair. He will inflict that punishment when He wills. But if the punishment has come, then no one can escape from it.

Regarding answering greetings to non-Muslims, the scholars have different opinions. Ibn 'Abbas, asy-Sya'bi, and Qatadah stated that answering greetings to non-Muslims is obligatory, just as answering greetings to fellow Muslims. Meanwhile, Imam Malik and Syafi'i stated that it is not obligatory, in the sense that it is only permissible. If they offer greetings, then it is sufficient for us to answer with "'alaika."

At the end of this verse, Allah firmly refutes their assumption that they will surely be put into Hell. They will be burned to ashes in it. Hell is the worst place of return prepared for the disbelievers.
text.9:
Then Allah directs His command to the believers, that they should never hold secret consultations among themselves with the aim of committing sin, fostering enmity, and disobeying Allah and the Messenger.

If they do hold secret consultations, it is permitted, but the topics discussed in the consultation should only be about goodness, discussing good ways, performing acts of piety, and avoiding evil deeds. It should be known that Allah knows everything; nothing escapes His knowledge. Therefore, no matter how secret the consultation is, He will surely know it.

And whoever disobeys Allah and His Messenger and transgresses His limits - He will put him into the Fire to abide eternally therein, and he will have a humiliating punishment. (an-Nisa'/4: 14)

In a hadith, it is explained as follows:

"If you are three, then two of you should not whisper to each other without including the third until you join other people, because that attitude saddens his feelings." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim)
text.10:
In this verse, it is explained that whispering and holding secret consultations to incite hostility and conflict are the efforts and actions of Satan. He encourages people to do so, so that they disobey Allah and His Messenger. That is Satan's life goal. He has influenced humans since their ancestor, the Prophet Adam. The more people he can tempt, the more friends he will have in hell.

It is also explained that Satan's effort is to cause sadness in the hearts of believers. The whispering and secret consultations carried out by the Jews and the hypocrites caused a feeling of insecurity in the hearts of the believers. In reality, the misfortune of mankind that Satan strives for will not be realized and implemented without the permission of Allah, the Almighty and the Determiner of all things.

At the end of this verse, Allah affirms that Muslims should not be provoked and feel insecure because of the whispering and secret agreements made by the disbelievers. All of it will not be realized unless Allah permits it. Therefore, every Muslim must put their trust (tawakal) in Allah and not believe in anyone except Him.
text.11:
This verse provides an explanation that if some Muslims are ordered by the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) to stand up to give an opportunity for a certain person to sit, or they are ordered to leave first, then they should stand up or leave, because he wants to give respect to those people, wants to be alone to think about religious matters, or carry out tasks that need to be completed immediately.

From this verse, the following can be understood:

1.  The Companions competed to find a place near the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) in order to easily hear the words he conveyed to them.

2.  The command to give a place to a newcomer is a recommendation, if possible, to create a sense of friendship between those present.

3.  Indeed, every person who gives ease to Allah's servants in doing good deeds, then Allah will also give ease to him in this world and in the hereafter.

Giving ease to fellow Muslims in association and striving to seek virtue and goodness, trying to please the hearts of their brothers, giving help, and so on are among the things recommended by the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). He said:

"Allah is always helping a servant as long as the servant is helping his brother." (Narrated by Muslim from Abu Hurairah)

Based on this verse, the scholars are of the opinion that people who are present in a gathering should comply with the provisions that apply in that gathering or obey the orders of those who organize the gathering.

If we study the meaning of the verse above, there is a provision determined by this verse, namely that people attending a gathering, whether arriving on time or late, should always maintain a good atmosphere, full of brotherhood and mutual tolerance. For those who arrive earlier, they should fill the front seats, so that those who come later do not need to step over or disturb those who have already been present. For those who arrive late, they should be content with the situation they find, such as not getting a seat. This is what is meant by the Prophet's (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) saying:

"Let no one make his friend stand up from his seat, then he sits in that place, but let them shift and make room." (Narrated by Muslim from Ibn 'Umar)

The end of this verse explains that Allah will raise the degree of those who believe, are obedient and submissive to Him, carry out His commands, avoid His prohibitions, strive to create a peaceful, safe, and secure atmosphere in society, as well as people of knowledge who use their knowledge to uphold the word of Allah. From this verse, it is understood that the people who have the highest degree in the sight of Allah are those who believe and have knowledge. Their knowledge is practiced in accordance with what Allah and His Messenger have commanded.

Then Allah affirms that He is All-Knowing of everything that humans do, nothing is hidden from Him. He will give a just reward according to the deeds that have been done. Good deeds will be rewarded with Paradise and evil and forbidden deeds will be rewarded with the torment of Hell.
text.12:
According to the narration of Ibn Abi Hatim from Ibn 'Abbas, it is explained that the companions greatly desired to ask the Messenger of Allah (saw) questions, thus burdening him. To lighten his burden, Allah revealed this verse, commanding them to give charity before meeting the Messenger of Allah.

This verse commands the believers that if they wish to speak privately with the Messenger of Allah (saw) about something important, they should give charity before engaging in that conversation. This command is to prove the greatness of the Messenger of Allah by glorifying him, and to bring benefit to the poor and needy. This is also to distinguish between those who truly love the Messenger of Allah and expect lessons from him, and the hypocrites whose words and deeds differ. On the other hand, this command prevents people from coming to the Messenger of Allah in large numbers without very important needs, thus occupying him.

According to Abu Muslim, Allah commanded this because the hypocrites, whose mouths professed faith while their hearts remained in disbelief, declared that they had entered Islam sincerely. To test that declaration, the command was revealed to give charity first before meeting the Messenger of Allah.

The benefit of giving charity is obtaining multiplied rewards from Allah, purifying and cleansing the wealth possessed, and cleansing the soul from the desire to accumulate wealth and make it the goal of life. The habit of giving charity can reduce the suffering of the poor and can also elevate the word of Allah. The wealth given in charity is given directly to those who are entitled to receive it, not given to the Prophet (saw), because among the purposes of charity is to glorify the Messenger of Allah (saw) and alleviate the burden of life for the poor and needy.

At the end of this verse, it is explained that if the person who is about to meet the Messenger of Allah (saw) does not have anything to give in charity, while he really needs to meet with him, then Allah gives him leniency by not requiring him to give charity.

The charity referred to here is voluntary charity (sunnah), not obligatory charity (wajib), and the amount is not specified, only according to the sincerity and ability of the giver. What this verse emphasizes is that Muslims should like to give charity, not be stingy, and be aware that the wealth they obtain is solely a tool to seek the pleasure of Allah. The requirement to give charity in this verse is to test the will of the hypocrites who have newly entered Islam.
text.13:
According to the narration of Ibn Abi Hatim from Thalhah from Ibn 'Abbas, it is said that after the revelation of verse 12 above, most people refrained from asking the Prophet Muhammad because of the obligation to pay charity (sedekah). Therefore, this verse was revealed as a rebuke to those who did not want to ask the Prophet Muhammad saw because of the obligation to pay charity.

This verse rebukes those who refrained from meeting the Prophet Muhammad saw because of the obligation to pay charity beforehand. In this verse it is stated, "Do you not come to the Prophet Muhammad saw because you fear poverty due to the obligation to pay charity beforehand, even though you greatly need his explanation and clarification?"

Allah then gave leniency to those people by *nasakh* (abrogating) verse 12 with verse 13, especially by stating, "If you are truly unable to carry out the recommendation to give charity before meeting the Prophet Muhammad saw, then you may meet to ask about something that needs clarification, without giving charity beforehand. Implement what has been explained in the best possible way."

Then Allah reminds of other obligations for the Muslims that must be carried out, namely that they establish prayer (salat) continuously according to the appointed times, never abandoning it in any circumstances. Prayer is of great benefit to humans, namely to perfect the submission of oneself to Allah, and to purify obedience and submission only to Him, not to others. Prayer can eliminate and erode the desires to commit vile and evil deeds.

Muslims are also commanded to give *zakat* if the conditions have been met. *Zakat* aims to purify the soul, eliminate the characteristics of stinginess in the heart, and help the suffering of the poor. Then it is emphasized that Muslims obey the commands of Allah and His Messenger and stop everything that He has forbidden.

At the end of this verse, Allah warns people to always be careful of all their actions and desires of their hearts. Because Allah knows everything, nothing escapes His knowledge. Based on His knowledge, He gives a fitting reward to every human being. Allah says:

"So whoever does an atom's weight of good will see it, And whoever does an atom's weight of evil will see it." (az-Zalzalah/99: 7-8)

And the Word of Allah:

"(Namely) that no bearer of burdens will bear the burden of another; And that there is not for man except that [good] for which he strives; And that his effort is going to be seen - Then he will be recompensed for it with the fullest recompense." (an-Najm/53: 38-41)
text.14:
Allah commands the Muslims to pay close attention to the hypocrites who take the Jews as their loyal friends, and they convey to the Jews secrets that they often hear from the Prophet (saw) and the Muslims. When they meet believers, they declare their faith and promise to participate in preaching and striving to uphold the word of Allah. However, when they meet the Jews, they portray the ugliness of the Muslims and promise together to destroy Islam and the Muslims. Allah says:

And of the people are some who say, "We believe in Allah and the Last Day," but they are not believers. They [think to] deceive Allah and those who believe, but they deceive not except themselves and perceive [it] not. In their hearts is disease, so Allah has increased their disease; and for them is a painful punishment because they [habitually] lie. (al-Baqarah/2: 8-10)

According to the narration of Ahmad and al-Hakim, received from as-Suddi from Ibn 'Abbas, this verse was revealed in connection with 'Abdullah bin Nabtal, a hypocrite who often conveyed the secrets of the Muslims to the Jews. One day, the Messenger of Allah (saw) was sitting in his house, and he said to the companions who were sitting around him, "There will come to you a person whose gaze is like the gaze of Satan. If he comes, do not speak to him." Not long after, a person came, namely 'Abdullah bin Nabtal, and the Messenger of Allah (saw) said to him, "Why do you and your friends revile me and my companions?" The man replied, "I will call my friends to prove the untruth of that accusation." After he and his friends arrived before the Messenger of Allah (saw), they swore by the name of Allah that they had never done what was accused of them.

Allah affirms that the hypocrites are not true believers, as they claim. They claim to believe solely to win the hearts of the believers and maintain good relations with them. The hypocrites are also not true Jews. They claim to be Jews solely to win the hearts of the Jews, so as to obtain protection from them. By being two-faced, they assume they can avoid the war that occurs between the Muslims and the disbelievers, including the Jews. Allah says:

Wavering between them, [belonging] neither to the one [group] nor to the other. And whomever Allah leaves astray - never will you find for him a way. (an-Nisa'/4: 143)

It is explained that the hypocrites do not hesitate to swear by the name of Allah to convince the believers and declare that they truly believe in Allah and His Messenger. Likewise, when they meet the Jews, they also swear that they are loyal friends and promise to help each other in facing the Muslims. The hypocrites know very well that their actions are not good and are forbidden.
text.15: This verse explains that because of their hypocrisy, Allah has prepared a severe punishment for them. From this verse, it can be understood that hypocrisy is an evil deed, harmful to society, and a major sin. The hypocrites deceive and reveal the secrets of the Muslims to their enemies, namely the Jews and the polytheists of Mecca. This action can lead to the destruction of the Islamic religion and the Muslims. Allah has prepared for them in the Hereafter the torment of Hell as punishment for their actions in this world.
text.16:
This verse explains the purpose behind their hypocrisy. By lying, reinforced with oaths, many Muslims believed them. Because they were thought to be truly believers, they were spared retaliation or expulsion by the Muslims.

Through this action, they gained advantages from the Muslims, who trusted their words, thus defending them. In this way, they were able to hinder others from embracing Islam by denigrating Islam and the Muslims. They could even instill fear and reluctance in the hearts of Muslims to participate in fighting alongside the Messenger of Allah. In one of His verses, Allah explains the attitude of the hypocrites:

Those who remained behind rejoiced in their staying [at home] after [the departure of] the Messenger of Allah and disliked striving with their wealth and their lives in the cause of Allah and said, "Do not go forth in the heat." Say, "The fire of Hell is more intense in heat" - if they would but understand. (at-Taubah/9: 81)

Because of the great sins they had committed, it was fitting that the hypocrites receive a humiliating punishment in this world and the Hereafter, as a recompense for their deeds.
text.17:
In this verse, it is emphasized that the wealth and children of the hypocrites cannot help save and protect themselves from the punishment of Allah. This verse illustrates that the character and nature of the hypocrites is to feel proud of having many children and wealth, as if what they possess can defend and release them from the calamities that threaten them. Allah says:

And they say, "We are more (than you) in wealth and children, and we will not be punished." (Saba'/34: 35)

Because they receive great blessings in the world, the hypocrites feel that they are loved by Allah and will not be punished in the Hereafter. According to them, the image of the afterlife for a person is their worldly life. If someone is happy in worldly life, then they will certainly be happy in the afterlife as well. Conversely, if they are miserable in worldly life, then they will certainly be miserable in the afterlife as well. Their assumption is wrong, because the main purpose of life is to seek the pleasure of Allah. As long as a person seeks the pleasure of Allah in their life, they will be protected by Him, whether they appear to live comfortably or not.

At the end of this verse, it is emphasized that those who declare that their wealth and children can be used to protect themselves from the punishment of Allah will be inhabitants of Hell in the Hereafter. They will live in it with great suffering.
text.18:
Those who claim that their wealth and children can be used to avert Allah's punishment in the Hereafter will also lie before Allah on the Day of Reckoning. They will swear that they were truly among the believers, just as they swore while they were alive in the world, as if they could deceive Allah with that confession. They think that by lying like that, they will be able to avoid the punishment that will be inflicted upon them.

This verse indicates that a person's character and nature during their life in the world will be revealed by Allah in the Hereafter. If their character, nature, and temperament were good during their life in the world, then it will appear good in the Hereafter. Conversely, if their character, nature, and temperament were bad during their life in the world, it will appear bad in the Hereafter. In the world, they can still deceive the eyes of humans, while in the Hereafter, they will directly face Allah, the All-Knowing, the All-Powerful.

In other verses, Allah explains the attitude of the hypocrites in the Hereafter, namely:

And when it is said to them, "Do not cause corruption on the earth," they say, "We are but reformers." Unquestionably, it is they who are the corrupters, but they perceive [it] not. (al-Baqarah/2: 11-12)
text.19:
Allah explains that the reason the hypocrites mentioned above are cast into the fire of Hell is because their hearts and minds have been influenced by the whispers of Satan, so that they can no longer remember Allah, follow His commands, and avoid His prohibitions. What is good according to their minds is what is good according to their desires and lusts. Therefore, they swear oaths to attract the sympathy of others, as if what they say is the truth. Allah says:

And thus We have made for every prophet an enemy - devils from mankind and jinn, inspiring to one another decorated speech as a delusion. But if your Lord had willed, they would not have done it, so leave them and that which they invent. (al-An'am/6: 112)

At the end of this verse, it is emphasized that the hypocrites described above are the soldiers and messengers of Satan. They gather and hold secret consultations to commit sinful acts and create enmity among the Muslims. The purpose of their doing such things is to follow their own desires. These soldiers and messengers of Satan are those who are disobedient to Allah. Those who are disobedient to Allah will surely perish and be destroyed, and in the Hereafter they will be cast into Hell.
text.20:
This verse explains about those who oppose Allah, they do not heed His commands, do not obey His prohibitions, and are reluctant to perform the obligations that Allah has prescribed for them. They are among the humiliated because the Muslims will defeat them by fighting and capturing them. Some of them are even expelled from their lands.

This verse reminds the Muslims of Allah's punishment inflicted upon the polytheists of Mecca in the form of defeat at the *fath Makkah* (Conquest of Mecca). As a result of the Battle of the Trench (Perang Ahzab), the Jews were expelled from the city of Medina for violating the peace treaty with the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him). Those whom Allah has declared as humiliated cannot be honored by anyone, as stated in His word:

"Our Lord! Verily, whom You admit to the Fire, indeed, You have disgraced him; and never will the wrongdoers find any helpers." (Â'li 'Imran/3: 192)

This verse 20 is good news for the believers who are receiving very heavy trials that they will be able to defeat their enemies and the religion of Islam will flourish everywhere in the near future.
text.21:
Allah reminds mankind of His sunnah that has been established in Lauh Mahfudh and applies throughout time and in all places. This sunnah concerns the decree of Allah and His Messenger that will surely defeat everyone who disbelieves in Him. Among them, Allah has destroyed the people of Noah, the people of Lot, the people of Saleh, Pharaoh and his followers in various ways. Such victory will also be obtained by the Prophet Muhammad and his followers, and also everyone who truly implements the Islamic religion in the best possible way. This is the sunnatullah that applies to His servants. Allah says:

"And Our word has already gone forth to Our servants, the messengers, (that) they will surely be the victors. And indeed, Our soldiers will be those who overcome." (as-Saffat/37: 171-173)

At the end of this verse, it is emphasized again that Allah has absolute power, the power to help His Messenger and those who believe, and to defeat the disbelievers. No one in the heavens or on earth can resist His will. It is very easy for Him to carry out His will. Allah says:

"His command is only when He intends a thing that He says to it, "Be," and it is." (Yasin/36: 82)
text.22:
It is narrated by Ibn Abi Hatim, ath-Thabrani, Abu Nu'aim, and al-Baihaqi from Ibn 'Abbas that he said, "This verse was revealed concerning Abu Ubaidah bin 'Abdillah al-Jarrah, who, during the Battle of Badr, was constantly challenged to a duel by his father, 'Abdullah al-Jarrah. However, he always tried to avoid the duel. Because he was constantly sought out and pursued by his father, he was forced to fight him, and Abu Ubaidah killed his father. Thus, this verse was revealed."

This verse explains that the hypocrites are truly disbelievers, even more dangerous than those who openly declare their disbelief. The hypocrites referred to in this verse are those who always strive and plot to achieve their goals of destroying the religion of Islam and the Muslims. Disbelievers who do not oppose the Muslims or who do not try to destroy the religion of Islam and the Muslims are not included in this verse.

Muslims are forbidden from befriending disbelievers who are enemies of Islam because that means participating in the effort to destroy Islam and the Muslims. As for disbelievers who do not oppose the Muslims and do not try to destroy the religion of Islam, Muslims are allowed to befriend and associate with them, as was done by the Prophet Muhammad (saw) himself and the Companions. In accordance with Allah's saying:

"Allah does not forbid you from dealing kindly and justly with those who have not fought you because of religion and have not driven you out of your homes. Indeed, Allah loves those who act justly." (al-Mumtahanah/60: 8)

Then it is emphasized that if there are Muslims who are close friends with disbelievers who oppose Islam, then that is an unnatural attitude. Because it is impossible for believers who truly believe in Allah to befriend disbelievers who want to destroy Islam.

Thus, Muslims are asked to always be vigilant whenever there is hostility and conflict with disbelievers. They should never be close friends with them, because it will endanger the Muslims.

Allah explains that those who have been shown the strength of their faith and the sincerity of their hearts, such as Abu Ubaidah, are people who have had faith planted in their hearts. So they cannot bear to hear Allah and His Messenger being reviled, or the religion of Islam being belittled.

In addition to having strong faith, Allah has also strengthened their hearts and souls, creating inner peace and steadfastness in upholding the religion of Allah. Therefore, they cannot cooperate with those who oppose Islam and the Muslims.

At the end of this verse, the rewards that they will receive from Allah are explained, namely:

1.  In the Hereafter, they will be placed in Paradise full of delights, and beneath it rivers flow. They will abide therein forever.

2.  Allah is pleased and loves the deeds that they have done during their lives in the world and their condition in the Hereafter. They are also pleased and happy with the rewards that Allah has bestowed upon them sooner or later.

3.  They are among those who are honored by Allah because they have been willing to become soldiers of Allah and sacrifice everything they have to exalt His word.

4.  They are among the fortunate, because they have successfully carried out their life's task as servants of Allah in this world and in the Hereafter.
